channel.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 Cable News Network LP, LLLP.

image.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
image.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

item.title: How will ISIS react if leader dead?
item.description: Reports from Iraq's government suggest that Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi may have been hit in airstrikes, what will happen if they are correct?

item.title: Three words spark Mexican outrage
item.description: The careless words of a lawyer anger Mexicans reeling from a massacre of students.

item.title: Iconic car that made history
item.description: CNN's Fred Pleitgen finds that driving the legendary motor is a nerve-wracking adventure.

item.title: 'Big Bang Theory' actress dies at 62
item.description: Carol Ann Susi, whose brash Brooklyn accent reverberated on the hit television series "Big Bang Theory, " has died after a battle with cancer.

item.title: Bill Cosby rape claims won't go away
item.description: It was not the sort of meme Bill Cosby wanted to generate.

item.title: Climate deal is 'watershed moment'
item.description: For the world's two largest economies -- and largest emitters of greenhouse gas -- to announce a sustained commitment to reducing carbon emissions by almost a third by the year 2030 is a watershed moment for climate politics on so many fronts.

item.title: Australia out in cold on climate
item.description: As the U.S. and China announce ambitious climate change targets, where does the move leave the G20 summit, and its host, Australia?

item.title: Ebola is not a death sentence
item.description: Ebola is not a death sentence. That is the lesson to the world from the release this week of Dr. Craig Spencer from a hospital in New York.

item.title: Study: Marijuana changes your brain
item.description: Using marijuana at an early age could have long-term consequences on your brain. It may even lower your IQ. That's according to a new study in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (PNAS).

item.title: Women's bodies being weaponized
item.description: A nonprofit's attempt to expose -- and stop -- the degrading street harassment women face every day has turned dangerously ugly.

item.title: Obama seeks strategy review on ISIS, Assad -- sources
item.description: The U.S. President has ordered an overhaul of policy on Syria, recognizing Bashar al-Assad's removal may be key to defeating ISIS, sources say.

item.title: Assad in U.S. crosshairs
item.description: Elise Labott reports the White House is reviewing new strategies to defeat ISIS, including Bashar al-Assad's removal.

item.title: U.S. studying ISIS recruitment
item.description: U.S. law enforcement views the case of three teenage Colorado girls who wanted to join ISIS as a good opportunity to study how the militant group recruits young people in the West, U.S. law enforcement officials told CNN.

item.title: Senator: War 'without legal authority'
item.description: Sen. Tim Kaine said Wednesday there's no legal authority for the current U.S. mission against ISIS in Iraq and Syria.

item.title: FIFA clears Russia, Qatar bids
item.description: FIFA has released the results of an independent investigations into the 2018 and 2022 world cup bidding processes.

item.title: Blast at near Egyptian embassy, Libya
item.description: A car bomb exploded near the Egyptian embassy in Tripoli on Thursday morning, the Libyan state news agency reported.

item.title: World leaders gather in Myanmar
item.description: What a difference two years makes.

item.title: Rights focus at ASEAN for Obama
item.description: U.S. President Barack Obama visits Myanmar for the ASEAN summit, but the country's human rights record could dominate the agenda.

item.title: Philae probe lands on comet
item.description: The Philae probe lands on a comet -- a historic first -- and sends back its first photos but mission control is worried anchoring harpoons have failed.

item.title: Probe lands, fails to anchor
item.description: Rosetta mission controllers are sure the lander is on Philae, but it is not anchored to Comet 67P. CNN's Fred Pleitgen reports.

item.title: Landing was biggest test
item.description: Hala Gorani speaks to ESA scientist Matt Taylor about what they're hoping to learn from the Philae lander on Comet 67P.

item.title: UK police arrest terror suspect
item.description: British authorities on Thursday morning arrested a 27-year-old man on suspicion of financing terrorist acts, police said.

item.title: Bin Laden SEAL reveals details
item.description: The former Navy SEAL who says he shot and killed Osama bin Laden had just returned from his 11th deployment when he was called back for the 2011 raid on the U.S.'s most wanted terrorist's Pakistan compound.

item.title: India sterilization doc arrested
item.description: The doctor at the center of the botched sterilization procedures that left more than a dozen women in India dead has been arrested.

item.title: Injured test pilot questioned
item.description: The surviving pilot of Virgin Galactic SpaceShipTwo told authorities he was unaware the feather system had been unlocked early by his co-pilot.

item.title: Female bomber hits Nigeria school
item.description: A female suicide bomber on Wednesday blew herself up at a teacher training college in central Nigerian town of Potiskum, killing one and injuring seven others, witnesses said.

item.title: 'Rare' arrest of Israel policeman
item.description: An Israeli border policeman has been detained in connection with the shooting death of a Palestinian teenager, an arrest that a human rights advocate described as "incredibly rare."

item.title: U.S. sailors attacked in Turkey
item.description: Three U.S. Navy sailors were assaulted and had bags placed over their heads during a stop in Istanbul, Turkey, according to U.S. military officials.

item.title: Tennis: Djokovic crushes Wawrinka
item.description: Novak Djokovic has plenty of reasons to feel on top of the world -- but one more victory at the ATP World Tour finals will mean he ends 2014 as the leading ranked player on the planet.

item.title: Long-range patrols near U.S. planned
item.description: Russia plans to send long-range bombers to patrol the western Atlantic and eastern Pacific waters, the nation's defense minister said, amid escalating tensions with the West over Ukraine.

item.title: Russia 'advancing into Ukraine'
item.description: A NATO commander says Russian tanks, Russian artillery, Russian air defense systems and Russian troops have crossed the border into increasingly fragile Ukraine.

item.title: Russian troops, tanks near border
item.description: Ukraine prepares for fighting as Russian forces move weapons and troops into the country. CNN's Jim Sciutto reports.

item.title: How has violence escalated?
item.description: Wolf Blitzer talks to Daniel Baer, U.S. Amb. to Org. for Sec. & Cooperation in Europe about the recent violence in the region.

item.title: Discovered: Funny, rude medieval doodles
item.description: My personal favorite is this. At the top of a page of angular medieval text -- full of theological extrapolations and religious devotion -- is a cartoon of a deadpan dog.

item.title: How Victorians dressed for death
item.description: Today, mourning a death in the family often means donning the most formal black outfit in one's closet for one solemn afternoon. But 150 years ago, it was a reason to stash away one's current best and purchase a whole new grief-appropriate wardrobe.

item.title: China: No more 'weird' buildings
item.description: The Chinese leadership has called for less "weird architecture" to be built in the country. Does it mean the end of unusual structures like these?

item.title: Louis Vuitton's Paris landmark
item.description: Luxury enthusiasts, rejoice: Louis Vuitton is bringing its upscale sensibilities to the art world.

item.title: The greatest beards in history
item.description: When it comes to facial hair, there are few more passionate advocates than Phil Olsen.

item.title: 10 works of art that shocked the world
item.description: As the Turner Prize turns 30 years old, we look at the formula for controversy and what the work we hate says about our society.

item.title: The most amazing train stations
item.description: Whether they're blasting over the tracks in Germany or Japan, trains offer travelers a chance to sit back and relax as they ride through some of the world's most incredible scenery.

item.title: Why Philae's space odyssey matters
item.description: Drama could inspire people back on Earth to new heights, says former astronaut Leroy Chiao.

item.title: It's complicated: Watch sells for $24.4M
item.description: The most "complicated" handmade watch in the world has been sold at auction for an historic $24.4 million.

item.title: Things to do in NYC before you die
item.description: A Gotham native suggests the best that the city that never sleeps has to offer.

item.title: 'Big Bang Theory' actress dies at 62
item.description: Carol Ann Susi, whose brash Brooklyn accent reverberated on the hit television series "Big Bang Theory, " has died after a battle with cancer.

item.title: Solar road opens in the Netherlands
item.description: The world's first road capable of turning sunlight into energy officially opened for traffic Wednesday in the Netherlands.

item.title: The timeless Lisu of Thailand
item.description: With their distinctive, colorful headwear, Lisu women stand out from the lush green fields of northern Thailand.

item.title: Most luxurious train in the world?
item.description: Experience Africa's savannah in style aboard the world's "most luxurious train."

item.title: The 10 worst people at the gym
item.description: You've made the honorable effort of getting your butt to the gym. Little do you know, the battle has only just begun.

item.title: Jesus: Married...with children?
item.description: A new book about a 'lost gospel' sounds more "Da Vinci Code" than "Bible."

item.title: Trapped and dangling 68 floors above NYC
item.description: How two window washers were rescued from their near vertical rig.

item.title: How they did it
item.description: Anderson Cooper reports on a rescue 68 floors above Ground Zero, as workers dangled from scaffolding along the building.

item.title: Photos: Scaffolding fails
item.description: New York emergency crews rescued two workers trapped on a window-washing scaffold dangling perilously at the 69th floor of the One World Trade Center building.

item.title: The apartheid you've never heard of
item.description: Myanmar's Rohingya, trapped in rural ghettos, live in fear of violence.

item.title: Climate: 'Once in a decade chance'
item.description: Extinctions, droughts, rising sea levels, bigger and more dangerous storm events; nature has been speaking to us. It's telling us we are taking too much from the planet and saving too little. My colleagues and I at Conservation International (CI) have been listening and now is the time for the world to act.

item.title: It's a '100m run while playing chess'
item.description: Ai Fukuhara's face is a picture of concentration as she crouches over the table tennis table, batting ball after ball back to her opponent.

item.title: Writers need more than prayer to live
item.description: He says he got about $40 for 6.8 million plays in 3 months -- the song was 'Living on a Prayer.'

item.title: Six other cool space missions
item.description: It's hard to top the tricky, first-ever space landing on a comet, broadcast live on the Internet.

item.title: It's APEC's funniest home videos
item.description: David Rothkopf says why would we care about trade deals, ISIS or Ebola when we can focus on Putin putting a shawl on China's first lady, Obama chewing gum and other nonstories that make the viewing public seem like an adolescent boy

item.title: 'Walking Dead' on the U.S. zombie trail
item.description: Zombie-obsessed fans can follow the tracks of their favorite "Walking Dead" survivors in Atlanta and beyond.

item.title: Training for success in your sleep
item.description: A sport sleep coach's top 10 tips on performance snoozing.

item.title: Singer: 'Do I LOOK like I have Ebola?'
item.description: Singer recalls being on receiving end of Ebola hysteria in NYC.

item.title: Soccer stars donate oranges
item.description: Football players donate 20 tons of tangerines to children in Ukraine's war zone.

item.title: This product made its debut during WWI
item.description: Richard Quest looks at how WWI gave the zipper its first market, and meets a man who has spent over 70 years selling them.

item.title: Worst celeb in-flight meltdowns
item.description: Cranberries singer Dolores O'Riordan was arrested Monday after allegedly assaulting a member of airline staff on a transatlantic flight and headbutting a police officer who tried to arrest her.

item.title: Pentagon wants flying aircraft carrier
item.description: Got any ideas on how to make a flying aircraft carrier?

item.title: ISIS' latest propaganda angle
item.description: Arwa Damon reports for "The Lead" live from Turkey on the latest propaganda from ISIS.

item.title: Where are the world's best hotels?
item.description: As the new year approaches, many travelers are looking for inspiration on where to head in 2015.

item.title: Models strut in U.N. chambers
item.description: It's one of the more unusual places to hold a fashion show: the United Nations.

item.title: Dare you try bridge's glass walkway?
item.description: Landmark crossing over the River Thames becomes latest global attraction to install vertical drop views.

item.title: Thieves drain pumps in latest crime wave
item.description: It's a multi-million-dollar crime, but it looks just like a guy pumping gas.

item.title: Lanterns 'soar to the heavens'
item.description: The Loi Krathong festival has been celebrated throughout Thailand for centuries, usually to mark the end of the rainy season.

item.title: Putin's cover-up covered up
item.description: China's censors snuff out an act of chivalry by Russia's president.

item.title: Sex museums: A global guide
item.description: Displaying everything from Catherine the Great's "naughty chair" to a 5.5-foot long whale penis, these erotica exhibits aren't for the prudish.

item.title: Sky-high designs taste success
item.description: Skyscraper greenhouse and green skyscrapers win life-in-the-skies title.

item.title: Separated at birth, reunited on Facebook
item.description: Forget Friends Reunited, Facebook brought these twins back together.

item.title: Why West's age of triumph is over
item.description: The fall of the Berlin Wall was overwhelmingly positive. But the "Age of Triumph," if it ever existed, is over, writes Malcolm Rifkind.

item.title: Stasi files: history's biggest jigsaw?
item.description: 25 years on, workers are fitting together 600 million pieces of the Stasi's shredded files.

item.title: Cycling the Death Strip: Berlin by bike
item.description: A lone saxophonist plays in the shadow of an overpass while a horde of cyclists looks down at a set of tangled train tracks.

item.title: ISIS 'cub' fighter, 15, saved by father
item.description: "Yasir" says the first time he saw a beheading he didn't eat for two days, repulsed by the scene -- not the actual act. But ISIS gave him such purpose his father had to trick him into leaving.

item.title: Why China still needs the U.S.
item.description: Despite China's inexorable economic rise, the U.S. is still an indispensable ally, especially in Asia, writes Kerry Brown.

item.title: How good is China's 'stealth' fighter?
item.description: China unveils its next-gen fighter. But what are its capabilities?

item.title: China's military machine on display
item.description: Stealth planes and drones present China as an aerospace power.

item.title: China shows off jet
item.description: China shows off its new stealth fighter jet, but did it steal the design from an American company? Brian Todd reports.

item.title: China's 'stealth' fighter
item.description: Zhuhai's Air Show has always been a venue for surprises, usually first-time showings of advanced Chinese military hardware.

item.title: Russian patrols
item.description: Russia plans to send long-range bombers to patrol the Gulf of Mexico and the Caribbean, the nation's defense minister said, amid escalating tensions with the West over Ukraine.

item.title: Obama on Syria
item.description: President Barack Obama has asked his national security team for another review of the U.S. policy toward Syria after realizing that ISIS may not be defeated without a political transition in Syria and the removal of President Bashar al-Assad, senior U.S. officials and diplomats tell CNN.

item.title: ISIS child fighter
item.description: Just two weeks ago, Yasir was regularly strapped into an explosive vest and handed a pistol, an AK-47 and a radio to stand guard at an ISIS base in the eastern Syrian city of Deir Ezzor.

item.title: Rosetta
item.description: Rosetta mission controllers have given the final go ahead for an attempted landing on Comet 67P, the European Space Agency (ESA) announced on the mission's official Twitter account on Wednesday.

item.title: Landing on comet
item.description: Rosetta mission controllers are unsure if the Philae probe is anchored to Comet 67P, CNN's Fred Pleitgen reports.

item.title: Berlin celebrates fall of the Wall
item.description: Germans celebrate the 25th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall, which led to reunification of a divided Germany.

item.title: See planet 450 light-years away
item.description: High-powered ALMA telescope captures a planet being born 450 light years away.

item.title: 'Batman' director goes to space
item.description: Christopher Nolan's "Interstellar" is an intergalactic voyage through space and time.

item.title: Hope for Nigerian schoolgirls?
item.description: Isha Sesay explains why the Nigerian girls, once seemingly so close to release, still haven't come home.

item.title: Therapy on wheels in Sweden
item.description: Taxi Stockholm is offering free therapy sessions in the Swedish capital. CNN's Jim Boulden explains how it works.

item.title: Ferrari's elite range
item.description: Ferrari is making six "invite-only" super cars that are available only to the most elite car lovers. CNNMoney's Alanna Petroff reports.

item.title: In jail with ISIS
item.description: In an interview with three ISIS prisoners, CNN's Ivan Watson is told he "would be tortured for sure."

item.title: 'Interstellar' launches
item.description: CNN's Neil Curry reports on the Red Carpet Premiere of Interstellar in London.

item.title: Paralyzed man walks
item.description: A man paralyzed from the chest down is able to walk again after undergoing pioneering surgery. CNN's Isa Soares reports.

item.title: Chocolate you can wear
item.description: CNN's Jonathan Mann takes a look at edible couture.

item.title: Cinematic treasures
item.description: CNN's Neil Curry reports on the work being done to prevent the British film archive from being lost forever.

item.title: 'The 12 Labors of Putin'
item.description: A Moscow art exhibit is celebrating President Vladimir Putin's birthday by portraying him as a hero of mythic proportions.

item.title: My mother deserved to die with dignity
item.description: Dying with dignity is more than just for the person who is dying. It's for their loved ones.

item.title: To be a black cat on Halloween
item.description: From ancient superstitions to modern photography, black cats face their share of unique issues -- especially this time of year.

item.title: Perspective-defying photos
item.description: It all started when she kissed the Great Sphinx of Giza.

item.title: Capturing a solar eclipse
item.description: If there's one thing we've learned about the CNN iReport community, it's that you all love to capture celestial events.

item.title: I'm a feminist, and I converted to Islam
item.description: I am a Muslim, but I wasn't always. I converted to Islam in November 2001, two months after 9/11.

item.title: China's 55 ethnic minorities
item.description: For a year, journalist and author David Eimer traveled the edges of China exploring a side of the country that obliterates expectations.

item.title: Michelin's 'undisputed leader' in cuisine
item.description: Tokyoites may brag about having the most Michelin stars in the world, but Hong Kongers can actually eat in theirs without breaking the bank.

item.title: Beating smog in style
item.description: High fashion isn't often inspired by environmental hazards, but as air pollution levels soared in Beijing on Tuesday, models at China Fashion Week walked the runway wearing designer respiratory face masks.

item.title: Taking 'selfies' with a drone
item.description: What comes in a white cardboard box, weighs little more than a kilogram and can be purchased in a few clicks from Amazon?

item.title: Flipping iPhones in Hong Kong
item.description: It's Wednesday afternoon, and it's packed in one of Hong Kong's three huge Apple Stores.
